Forests with a high density of trees typically have a darker environment due to several interrelated factors. Firstly, the thick canopy formed by closely packed trees absorbs a significant amount of sunlight, preventing it from reaching the forest floor. The leaves, branches, and trunks of these trees serve as barriers to light, with each layer of foliage capturing or reflecting some of the light that penetrates the canopy above it. As a result, only a small fraction of the sunlight can filter through to the ground. This effect is further compounded in deciduous forests, where layers of leaves can be especially dense.

Another factor contributing to the darker environment is the cumulative shadowing effect of the trees. In a dense forest, trees stand very close to one another, casting shadows on each other and on the ground. During many times of the day, when the sun is not directly overhead, much of the light is blocked by the trees themselves, adding to the overall darkness of the environment.

Additionally, the type of foliage and the nature of the forest can influence the level of darkness. Forests with evergreen trees, for example, maintain their leaves year-round, which means the canopy remains relatively thick throughout the year, consistently limiting the amount of light that reaches the forest floor.

In summary, the high density of trees in forests leads to a darker environment primarily due to the extensive canopy that absorbs and blocks sunlight, along with the shadowing effects caused by the close proximity of the trees. These factors collectively reduce the intensity of light at ground level, creating dimmer conditions.
